{{Refimprove|date=July 2007}} {{Infobox Minister |name = Johan August Gripenstedt |image = Johan August Gripenstedt.jpg |imagesize = 250px |office = [[Minister without Portfolio]] |term_start = 7 April 1848 |term_end = 1856 |monarch = [[Oscar I of Sweden|Oscar I]] |predecessor = [[Claës Günther]] |successor = [[Carl Göran Mörner]] |office2 = [[Minister for Finance (Sweden)|Minister for Finance]] |term_start2 = 28 May 1856 |term_end2 = 4 July 1866 |monarch2 = [[Oscar I of Sweden|Oscar I]] (1844–1859),
[[Charles XV of Sweden|Charles XV]] (1859–1866) |predecessor2 = [[Carl Otto Palmstierna]] |successor2 = [[Gustaf Lagercrantz]] |birth_date = {{Birth date|1813|8|11|df=yes}} |birth_place = [[Holstein|Duchy of Holstein]], [[German Confederation]] |death_date = {{Death date and age|1874|7|13|1813|8|11|df=yes}} |death_place = [[Stockholm]], Sweden |party = [[Independent (politician)|Independent]] |alma_mater = [[Military Academy Karlberg]] }} [[Baron]] '''Johan August Gripenstedt''' (11 August 1813 – 13 July 1874) was a [[Sweden|Swedish]] businessman and politician. During his political career, Gripenstedt was a member of the Swedish [[Riksdag of the Estates|Estates Assembly]] (as a representative of the [[nobility]]) from 1840 to 1848, [[Minister without Portfolio]] from 1848 to 1856, [[Minister for Finance (Sweden)|Minister for Finance]] from 1856 to 1866, and [[Parliament of Sweden|Member of Parliament]] from 1867 to 1873. He is best known for his ten years tenure as Minister for Finance, during which he introduced many [[Economic liberalism|liberal economic]] reforms and fought for issues such as [[free trade]] and state owned railways. == Early life and military career == Johan August Gripenstedt was born in the [[Holstein|Duchy of Holstein]], then part of the [[German Confederation]], where his parents lived at the time. His father Jakob Gripenstedt was a retired [[Sweden|Swedish]] [[Officer (armed forces)|officer]]. His mother Helena Kristina (née Weinschenck) was the daughter of a German physician. The Gripenstedt family's earliest descendandt was a man named Hieronimus Berger, born in the [[Courland]] region of modern-day [[Latvia]], who immigrated to Sweden and was [[Ennoblement|ennobled]] with name Gripenstedt in 1691. Johan August Gripenstedt came to Sweden with his family at the age of four. He grew up at the estate of [[Gräfsnäs]] in [[Västergötland]] and later, when the estate's [[fee tail]] ended following his uncle's death in 1821, at the nearby estate of [[Holmängen]]. Gripenstedt and his brothers were educated at home, and following his examination in the spring of 1827 he was registered at [[Uppsala University]]. However, Gripenstedt's plans for a civilian career promptly changed and in 1828 he left the university for the [[Military Academy Karlberg|Royal War Academy]] in [[Stockholm]]. After completing his education at the Royal War Academy, Gripenstedt became a [[Second Lieutenant]] at the [[Göta Artillery Regiment]] in [[Gothenburg]], in 1831. Following further education at the Marieberg Upper Military School from 1832 to 1835, Gripenstedt was in 1837 promoted to the rank of Lieutenant and, in 1841, to the rank of [[Artillery Staff Officer]]. At this time however, Gripenstedt had already started a new career as a politician. In 1846 he was at his own request released from military service. == Politics and entrepreneurship == Gripenstedt first entered politics as a representative of the [[Swedish nobility|nobility]] at the [[Riksdag of the Estates|Riksdag]] of 1840–1841. He soon distinguished himself as a skillful speaker and was elected to the parliament's [[Committee on the Accords (Swedish Riksdag)|Committee on the Accords]] ({{lang-sv|bevillningsutskottet}}). Through his marriage into the [[Anckarswärd family]] in 1842, Gripenstedt became affiliated with the "liberal landowners'"-faction of the parliament, led by [[Carl Henrik Anckarswärd]]. In the end of 1841, Gripenstedt was elected to the parliament's powerful [[Committee on the Constitution (Swedish Riksdag)|Committee on the Constitution]], which at this time worked on a new representative reform. As opposed to the conservative group of the parliament, Gripenstedt was a strong adherent of [[Election#Difficulties with elections|free elections]] and [[general suffrage]] long before this was realized in Sweden. During start of the Riksdag of 1847, Gripenstedt was elected to the [[Committee of the State (Swedish Riksdag)|Committee of the State]]. As a trustee of Carl Henrik Anckarswärd, and later as the owner of estates such as [[Nynäs Castle]] in [[Södermanland]], Gripenstedt became a successful entrepreneur within the grain exports and iron industry. In 1848 Gripenstedt was selected, to many's surprise, by King [[Oscar I of Sweden|Oscar I]] to serve as [[Minister without Portfolio]] ({{lang-sv|konsultativt statsråd}}) in his cabinet. The post was first offered to the conservative [[Jacob Nils Tersmeden]], who declined, and King Oscar wanted to rejuvenate his cabinet why he selected Gripenstedt instead. Gripenstedt also served as acting [[Minister for Finance (Sweden)|Minister for Finance]] from 10 January to 21 October 1851. On 28 May 1856 he was appointed as (permanent) Minister for Finance. Influenced by French liberal thinkers such as [[Alexis de Tocqueville]] and [[Frédéric Bastiat]], Gripenstedt was a leading proponent of [[free trade]] and other liberal reforms. He succeeded in getting the Swedish parliament to gradually abolish [[tariff]]s and reduce customs duties. In 1865 he signed trade agreements with France, the [[Zollverein|German Customs Union]] and [[Prussia]], which resulted in greatly reduced customs duties on many products. His optimistic descriptions in the Swedish parliament in 1857 of the economic situation of the country, the so-called "flower paintings" ({{lang-sv|blomstermålningarna}}), paved the way for a fast expansion of the [[Rail transport in Sweden|Swedish railroad network]], which was financed by loans on the international market. Gripenstedt opposed an activist [[foreign policy]], which he saw as a threat to the economic stability of the country. As the [[Denmark|Danish]]-[[German Confederation|German]] conflict over the [[Schleswig-Holstein Question]] grew more tense, Gripenstedt and then [[Prime Minister for Justice]] [[Louis De Geer (1818-1896)|Louis De Geer]] (also a devoted liberal) stopped King [[Charles XV of Sweden|Charles]]' plan for Swedish military support in the [[Second Schleswig War|upcoming war]]. [[Image:Johan August Gripenstedt, Svenska Familj-Journalen.png|thumb|250px|Johan August Gripenstedt]] Following his retirement as Minister for Finance on 4 July 1866, Gripenstedt served as a member of the [[lower house]] of the new bicameral [[Parliament of Sweden|parliament]] from 1867 to 1873. He died in [[Stockholm]] on 13 July 1874 (aged sixty), following a long period of illness. He is buried at [[Bälinge Church, Uppsala|Bälinge Church]] in [[Södermanland]]. == Family life == Gripenstedt married his wife Eva Anckarswärd, the oldest daughter of Colonel [[August Anckarswärd]] and Sofia Ulrika Anckarswärd (née [[Bonde]]), in 1842. Together with his wife he had five children. == Titles and honours == Gripenstedt was elected a member of the [[Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences]] ({{lang-sv|Kungliga Vetenskapsakademien}}) in 1858. He was ennobled by King Charles as a [[baron]] ({{lang-sv|friherre}}) on 4 May 1860. == Legacy == Gripenstedt is widely seen as one of the most decisive and influential persons in Swedish political history. As a great speaker and with a good sense of political intrigues and tactics, Gripenstedt was successful in almost everything that he took on. He is not only credited as the one who initiated and guided Sweden's transition to a [[Capitalism|capitalist]] economy, but also as one of the main architects of the "liberal revolution" of the 1800s. His reforms changed Sweden definitely into a new direction of liberalized economy and free trade. These new policies ultimately paved the way for the [[Industrialization of Sweden|Swedish industrialization]]. The period from 1870 to 1970 is commonly referred to in Swedish history as the "[[Hundred Years of Growth]]". During this period Sweden developed from one of the poorest countries in Europe to one of the richest and most prosperous countries in the world. In the book ''[[Historiens 100 viktigaste svenskar]]'' ("100 Most Important Swedes in History"), written by Niklas Ekdal and Petter Karlsson, Gripenstedt was ranked as the twelfth most important Swede in history.{{citation |last1=Ekdal |first1=Niklas |last2=Karlsson |first2=Petter |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Historiens 100 viktigaste svenskar |publisher=Forum |place=[[Stockholm]] |year=2009 |isbn=978-91-37-13402-4}} == References == == Further reading == * {{citation |first=Olle |last=Gasslander |title=J.A. Gripenstedt : statsman och företagare |year=1949 |publisher=Gleerup |place=[[Lund]]}} * {{citation |first=Per T. |last=Ohlsson |authorlink=Per T. Ohlsson |title=100 år av tillväxt : Johan August Gripenstedt och den liberala revolutionen |year=1994 |publisher=Bromberg |place=[[Stockholm]] |isbn=91-7608-650-X}} == External links == {{commons}} * [http://www.frihandel.nu/varfor/gripenstedt.asp Johan August Gripenstedt - den svenska frihandelns fader] {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{succession box |title = [[Minister without Portfolio]] |years = 1848 – 1856 |before = [[Claës Efraim Günther]] |after = [[Carl Göran Mörner]]}} {{succession box |title = [[Minister for Finance (Sweden)|Minister for Finance]] |years = 1856 – 1866 |before = [[Carl Otto Palmstierna]] |after = [[Gustaf Lagercrantz]]}} {{s-end}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gripenstedt, Johan August}} [[Category:1813 births]] [[Category:1874 deaths]] [[Category:Swedish nobility]] [[Category:Swedish military officers]] [[Category:Swedish businesspeople]] [[Category:Members of the Riksdag of the Estates]] [[Category:Swedish Ministers for Finance]] [[Category:Members of the lower house of the Riksdag]] [[Category:Members of the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences]] [[Category:19th-century Swedish politicians]] [[Category:19th-century Swedish businesspeople]]

{{More citations needed|date=October 2007}} {{Infobox person |image = |alt = |caption = |birth_name = John Stewart Donald Tory |birth_date = 1903 |birth_place = [[Toronto|Toronto, Ontario]], Canada |death_date = August 28, 1965 (aged 62) |death_place = |resting_place = |other_names = |known_for = |occupation = Lawyer |alma_mater = [[Osgoode Hall Law School]] LL.B.
[[Harvard Law School]] S.J.D. |nationality = [[Canadians|Canadian]] |parents = |relatives = [[John Tory]] (grandson) |spouse = Jean Arnold Tory |children = 3 (including [[John A. Tory]] and [[James Marshall Tory]]) }} '''John Stewart Donald Tory''' (1903 – August 28, 1965){{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1965/08/28/archives/john-s-d-tory-dies-an-industrialist-62.html|title=JOHN S. D. TORY DIES; AN INDUSTRIALIST, 62|access-date=2018-10-10|language=en}} was a [[Toronto]] lawyer and founder of the law firm [[Torys]]. ==Early life== Tory was born in [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]] to John Alexander Tory, Sr. (1869-1950) and Abigail Georgina Buckley (1875-1961). His father, John Alexander Tory, Sr., was the youngest of three children and was a company director who became the head of the Ontario division of Sun Life Assurance Company. Tory's great-grandfather, James Tory, was a soldier in the [[71st Regiment of Foot, Fraser's Highlanders|71st Scottish Regiment]]. He was captured and held as a prisoner of war during the [[American Revolution]]. He later settled in [[Nova Scotia]] in the 1780s.{{cite web|first=Sandra |last=Martin |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/john-a-tory-a-quiet-humble-man-who-shaped-canadian-dynasties/article4182147/?page=all |title=John A. Tory: A quiet, humble man who shaped Canadian dynasties |publisher=The Globe and Mail |date=April 9, 2011 |accessdate=December 1, 2012}} J.S.D. Tory attended [[Upper Canada College]] and the [[University of Toronto Schools]]. He graduated at the top of his class at [[Osgoode Hall Law School]], and earned an [[Doctor of Juridical Science|SJD]] from [[Harvard University]].{{Cite web|url=http://pds.lib.harvard.edu/pds/view/6796688?n=1112|title=Harvard Mirador Viewer|website=pds.lib.harvard.edu|access-date=2018-10-10}} ==Career== He was called to the Ontario bar and later worked at the W.N. Tilley law firm in Toronto for a few years. In 1941, he launched his own firm, [[Torys|Torys LLP]] with a focus on corporate law.{{cite web|url=http://www.torys.com/AboutTorys/History/Pages/default.aspx |title=About Torys |publisher=TORYS LLP |accessdate=October 28, 2014 }} Tory was also a director of [[Avro Canada|A.V. Roe Canada]]. A literary award at the University of Toronto was named in his honour. ==Personal life== He married Kathreen Jean Arnold. They had three children: daughter Virginia, and fraternal twin sons [[John A. Tory]] and [[James Marshall Tory]]. Both sons later joined his firm. His grandson is Toronto Mayor [[John Tory]], former [[Progressive Conservative Party of Ontario]] leader and member of his grandfather's firm. Tory and Arnold separated when their children were in their twenties. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.torys.com/AboutTorys/History/Pages/default.aspx Torys LLP biography of John S. D. Tory] {{DEFAULTSORT:Tory, John S. D.}} [[Category:People from Toronto]] [[Category:Tory family|John S.D.]] [[Category:Lawyers in Ontario]] [[Category:1965 deaths]] [[Category:Osgoode Hall Law School alumni]] [[Category:Harvard Law School alumni]] [[Category:1903 births]] [[Category:Upper Canada College alumni]] [[Category:Corporate lawyers]] [[Category:20th-century Canadian lawyers]] {{Canada-law-bio-stub}}

The station is owned by KBNP Radio, Inc. Programming: As Oregon's only, all-business news and financial information radio station since 1989, AM 1410 has aired programming for business owners and investors. Ray Lucia, Ron Insana, Lou Dobbs, Gary Kaltbaum, and the pulse of Wall Street are monitored through reports, interviews and LIVE call-in shows from the Business Talk Radio Network and Bloomberg Radio that keep listeners informed on global Markets and the investment world. Weekend programs focus on "how-to" shows dealing with everything in the work environment to home improvements experts, automotive technicians, travel experts, pet care and even GunTalk with Tom Gresham. ==Ownership== In March 2009, Alan M. Gottlieb applied to transfer control of KBNP Radio, Inc., the licensee of record for this radio station, to the [[Second Amendment Foundation]] and the Citizens Committee for the Right to Keep and Bear Arms, both of [[Bellevue, Washington]]. The transfer was approved by the FCC on March 27, 2009.{{cite web |publisher=FCC Media Bureau |title=Application Search Details (BTC-20090306ACO) |url=http://fjallfoss.fcc.gov/cgi-bin/ws.exe/prod/cdbs/pubacc/prod/app_det.pl?Application_id=1303186 |date=March 27, 2009}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.kbnp.com KBNP official website] *[http://www.saf.org/ Second Amendment Foundation] {{AM station data|KBNP}} *[https://licensing.fcc.gov/cgi-bin/prod/cdbs/forms/prod/getimportletter_exh.cgi?import_letter_id=43917&.pdf FCC History Cards for KBNP] {{Portland, Oregon Radio}} {{News/Talk Radio Stations in Oregon}} [[Category:Radio stations in Portland, Oregon|BNP]] [[Category:Business talk radio stations]] [[Category:Radio stations established in 1951]] [[Category:1951 establishments in Oregon]] [[Category:Business media in the United States]]

{{Infobox company | name = Korea Institute for Advancement of Technology (KIAT)

([[Hangul]]: 한국산업기술진흥원) | logo = Official Logo Korea Institute for Advancement of Technology.jpg | type = [[institute|Public Institute]] | founded = 2009 | location_city = [[Seoul]] | location_country = Republic of Korea | revenue = {{unbulleted list| [[United States dollar|US$]]1.17bn (2012)}}[http://erawatch.jrc.ec.europa.eu/erawatch/opencms/information/country_pages/kr/organisation/organisation_0009?tab=template&country=kr Erawatch Korea Institute for Advancement of Technology] | num_employees = {{unbulleted list| 257 (2012)}} | homepage = {{URL|www.kiat.or.kr}} }} The '''Korea Institute for Advancement of Technology (KIAT)''' is a quasi government-public institute under the Korean [[Ministry of Trade, Industry and Energy]]. Formed in May 2009, the main functions of KIAT include analyzing and formulating Korean R&D and industrial policy, acting as an industrial technology innovation funding agency, creating Korea's industrial and technological ecosystem, and fostering international technological cooperation. KIAT has an annual budget of circa one billion dollars, and employs 257 staff. (2012)[http://www.newsworld.co.kr/cont/article2009/0905-36.htm NewsWorld .NOVEMBER 2006] == History == KIAT was formed in May 2009 by the merger and consolidation of six previous Korean government and public institutes: ITEP (Korea Institute of Industrial Technology Evaluation and Planning), KOTEF (Korea Industrial Technology Foundation), KTTC (Korea Technology Transfer Center), IITA (Institution for Information Technology Advancement), KMAC (Korea Materials and Components Industry Agency), and KIDP (Korea Institute of Design Promotion). == KIAT Presidents == http://www.oecd.org/site/stigfke/48529471.pdf {{cite web | url=http://www.etnews.com/news/people/2822443_1617.html | title=[이사람]정재훈 Kiat 신임 원장, 두발을 땅에 딛고 일하겠다| date=2013-09-02}} {|border="1" cellpadding="5" cellspacing="0" align="left" |- ! scope="col" style="background:#efefef;" | Date ! scope="col" style="background:#efefef;" | President |- |May, 2009–September, 2013 |Kim Yong Geun (김용근) |- |September, 2013–present |Chung Jae Hoon (정재훈) |} == Project Funding and grants == In 2012, KIAT distributed circa US$940m in technology project grants and R&D funding.[http://k-economy.na.go.kr/site?siteId=site000003451&pageId=page000003607&bd_mode=read&bd_pageNumber=1&bd_searchTerm=&bd_searchKeyword=&bd_recordId=2012070031079 자료실 > 참고자료] == Events == KIAT is responsible for organizing numerous annual technology, R&D, and collaboration events. These include the tech+ forum and Eureka day events. === tech+ forum === The [[Tech Plus Forum]] ('tech+ forum') has been held since 2009 in Korea. It is a 'knowledge concert' that gathers leading experts in innovation and inspiration to discuss themed-topics over the course of a two-day event. The name Tech+ is derived from technology, economy, culture and humanity. In 2012, tech+ was held under the theme of ‘dream@technology'.[http://sunday.joins.com/article/view.asp?aid=28078 중앙 SUNDAY] === Eureka Day === [[EUREKA]] is a pan-European collaborative R&D network that was established in 1985. It currently has 41 full member countries [http://www.eurekanetwork.org/in-your-country In your country - EUREKA] and Korea is an associate member. KIAT acts as the EUREKA NCP (National Contact Point) for Korea, and since 2011 has held an annual Eureka day event to advance Korea-European cooperation and innovation via matchmaking and seminars.[http://nwww.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20110213000304 EUREKA connects Korea’s R&D sector-The Korea Herald][http://www.eurekanetwork.org/showevent?p_r_p_564233524_articleId=1329135&p_r_p_564233524_groupId=10137 2012 KOREA EUREKA Days - EUREKA Events - EUREKA] == References == {{Reflist}} == Notes == {{note|reference_name_stats}}Reference #4. Figures derived and calculated from Korean government official statistics, Knowledge Economy Committee, Korean National Assembly, accessed Jan 09, 2013. == External links == * [http://www.kiat.or.kr/ Homepage (Korean)] * [http://www.kiat.or.kr/site/main/index/index002.jsp/ Homepage (English)] * [http://techplusforum.com/html/te1.html/ techplus forum (English)] * [http://gpkorea.or.kr/engOmain.do?cmd=omain/ KIAT's Global Partnership Program (English)] * [http://www.eurekaday.kr/default.asp/ Eureka Day(English)] * [http://www.motie.go.kr/language/eng// Ministry of Trade, Industry and Energy (English)] [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:Technology strategy]] [[Category:Technology development]] [[Category:Innovation organizations]] [[Category:Innovation economics]] [[Category:Knowledge transfer]] [[Category:Organizations based in Seoul]]

{{main|World Branding Awards}}
[[File:World Branding Awards Trophy.jpg|thumb|The World Branding Awards trophy is on display at the [[Museum of Brands, Packaging & Advertising]] in London]] The '''List of World Branding Awards winners''' provide details of the winners of the [[World Branding Awards]], an international award presented to some of the best global and national brands for their work and achievements in [[brand management|branding]].<ref name=TTR>{{cite news|title=Taiwan’s Acer and Chatime Honoured at the 2014 World Branding Awards|url=http://taiwantradereview.com/taiwans-acer-and-chatime-honoured-at-the-2014-world-branding-awards/|accessdate=5 December 2014|publisher=Taiwan Trade Review|date=29 Oct 2014}}</ref> The awards are organised by the [[World Branding Forum]], a registered global non-profit organisation based in London.<ref name=star-maybank>{{cite news|title=Maybank awarded Brand of the Year at World Branding Forum|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/Business/Business-News/2014/10/29/Maybank-awarded-Brand-of-the-Year-at-World-Branding-Forum/?style=biz|accessdate=5 December 2014|publisher=The Star|date=29 Oct 2014}}</ref>
The first awards ceremony was held at [[Whitehall Court|One Whitehall Place]] at the [[Royal Horseguards Hotel]] in [[London]] on October 26, 2014. The event was hosted by [[David Croft (broadcaster)|David Croft]] from [[Sky Sports]].<ref name=yahoo-finance>{{cite news|title=Asian Brands Honoured at the 2014 World Branding Awards|url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/asian-brands-honoured-2014-world-160500286.html|accessdate=21 February 2015|publisher=Yahoo Finance|date=29 Oct 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150216100702/https://finance.yahoo.com/news/asian-brands-honoured-2014-world-160500286.html|archivedate=16 February 2015|df=}}</ref>
Sixty nine brands from 25 countries won an award.<ref name=boston>{{cite news|title=Apple, Coca-Cola, HSBC and Louis Vuitton Named "Brand of the Year" at the 2014 World Branding Awards|url=http://finance.boston.com/boston/news/read/28565434/Apple|accessdate=21 February 2015|publisher=Boston Times|date=28 Oct 2014}}</ref> Each brand is named "Brand of the Year" in their respective categories.<ref name=yahoo-finance/> The "Brand of the Year" logo is a [[trademark|registered trademark]].<ref name="EUIPO">{{cite web|title=World branding Awards Brand Of The Year|url=https://euipo.europa.eu/eSearch/#details/trademarks/014433148|website=EUIPO|publisher=European Union Intellectual Property Office|accessdate=8 February 2017}}</ref> The awards gave special recognition to [[Tony Fernandes]], Group CEO of [[AirAsia]] and Chairman of [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.]], naming him "Brand Builder of the Year" for his outstanding work in building the airline brand.<ref name=SunStar>{{cite news|title=AirAsia Awarded Brand of the Year in Airline Category|url=http://www.sunstar.com.ph/cagayan-de-oro/business/2014/11/04/airasia-awarded-brand-year-airline-category-374601|accessdate=5 December 2014|publisher=Sun Star|date=4 Nov 2014}}</ref>
The second part of the 2014-2015 awards, took place at the [[:fr:Hilton Paris Opéra]] in France on 24 March 2015. The Paris ceremony had an emphasis on food, beverage, luxury, fashion, lifestyle, hospitality, and service brands.<ref name=yahoo-fin-paris/> Fifty brands from 22 countries were awarded at this ceremony.<ref name=FNI-Paris>{{cite news|title=State Bank of India wins ‘Brand of the Year’ Award at The World Branding Awards|url=http://forevernews.in/state-bank-of-india-wins-brand-of-the-year-award-at-the-world-branding-awards/|accessdate=16 May 2015|publisher=Forever News India|date=30 March 2015}}</ref>
In 2015, 118 brands from 30 countries were honoured with an award. The ceremony took place at [[Kensington Palace]] in London. The event was hosted by [[Olivia Wayne]] from [[Sky Sports]].<ref name="reuters15"/>
In 2016, over 120,000 consumers from around the world voted for more than 2,800 brands from 35 countries. 210 brands from 30 countries were declared winners. The ceremony was held again in London's [[Kensington Palace]]. Guests included the United Arab Emirates Ambassador to the United Kingdom, Sulaiman Almazroui,<ref name="GADF16">{{cite news|last1=Noor|first1=Hibah|title=Dubai Duty Free wins Brand of the Year Award|url=http://www.dutyfreemagazine.ca/gulf-africa/industry-news/operator-news/2016/09/28/dubai-duty-free-wins-brand-of-the-year-award/#.WJsGun-8ZEY|accessdate=8 February 2017|publisher=Gulf-Africa Duty Free|date=28 September 2016}}</ref> and the Philippines Ambassador, Evan Garcia.<ref name="FilEmb">{{cite web|title=World Branding Awards recognize Philippine brands|url=http://londonpe.dfa.gov.ph/embassy-news/339-wbf2016|website=Embassy of the Philippines|accessdate=14 February 2017}}</ref> The event was hosted by David Croft.<ref name="TBN-KP16">{{cite news|title=Thai Brands among 210 Winners of the 2016 World Branding Awards at Kensington Palace|url=http://thaibusinessnews.com/readnews.php?id=116|accessdate=8 February 2017|publisher=Thai Business News|date=21 September 2016}}</ref>
In 2017, over 3,000 brands from 35 countries were nominated, and more than 135,000 consumers from around the world participated during the voting period. 245 Brands from 32 countries were awarded.<ref name="wba-2017">{{cite web|title=World Branding Awards - Winners 2017-2018|url=https://awards.brandingforum.org/winners-2017-2018/|publisher=World Branding Forum|accessdate=10 April 2018}}</ref>
In 2018, the Americas Edition of the awards saw over 80,000 consumers vote for more than 1,500 brands from 22 countries from Americas and the Caribbean. There were 81 brands from 16 countries awarded.<ref name="CaribbeanBusiness">{{cite news |title=Banco Popular among 81 winners at World Branding Awards |url=https://caribbeanbusiness.com/banco-popular-among-81-winners-at-world-branding-awards/ |accessdate=3 September 2018 |publisher=Caribbean Business |date=20 July 2018}}</ref>
The awards trophy is made in [[England]],<ref name=efx>{{cite web|title=EFX Acclaimed for World Branding Awards|url=http://www.awardefx.co.uk/uploads/email/efxnewsnovember14/newsnovember14.html|website=Award EFX|publisher=EFX|accessdate=21 February 2015}}</ref> and is on display at the [[Museum of Brands, Packaging & Advertising]] in London.<ref name=enquirer-herald>{{cite news|title=World Branding Forum Sponsors Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising Education Project|url=http://www.heraldonline.com/2015/02/09/6781165_world-branding-forum-sponsors.html?rh=1|accessdate=21 February 2015|publisher=Enquirer Herald|date=9 Feb 2015}}</ref> In 2016, a newly designed [[24 karat]] gold plated trophy was introduced for all winners. This new design is a solid trophy which highlights the "Brand of the Year" registered trademark logo.<ref name="AppleWorld-16">{{cite news|last1=Sellers|first1=Dennis|title=Apple among 210 winners of the 2016 World Branding Awards|url=https://www.appleworld.today/blog/2016/9/21/apple-among-210-winners-of-the-2016-world-branding-awards|accessdate=8 February 2017|publisher=Apple World Today|date=21 September 2016}}</ref>
== Winners of the World Branding Awards ==
=== 2018–2019 === The 2018 Americas Edition of the awards was held at [[Plaza Hotel|The Plaza]] on [[Fifth Avenue]] in [[New York City]].<ref name=CaribbeanBusiness/> [[File:New York - Manhattan - Plaza Hotel.jpg|thumb|300px|The 2018 America's Edition of the World Branding Awards were held at the [[Plaza Hotel]] on [[Fifth Avenue]] in [[New York City|New York]]]]

{{Spanish name|'''Álvarez'''|'''Renta'''}}
{{BLP sources|date=May 2010}}
'''Luis Álvarez Renta''' (born April 9, 1950) is a Dominican economist. Álvarez Renta was found liable by a federal jury in [[Miami]] of civil [[racketeering]] and illegal money transfers in a conspiracy to loot [[Baninter]] bank during its final months of existence in 2003, for which Álvarez Renta was ordered to pay $177 million to Dominican authorities in November 2005.<ref>[http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Barranco+Kircher+&+Vogelsang+Announces+Luis+Alvarez+Renta+Will+Appeal...-a0138579604 The Free Library]</ref>
==Biography== Luis Rafael Álvarez Renta was born in [[Caracas, Venezuela]]. His father, Virgilio Álvarez Saviñón, was a renowned and wealthy Dominican engineer who had been forced into exile during the dictatorship of [[Rafael Leónidas Trujillo]] in the Dominican Republic. Arriving in Venezuela with twenty dollars and a suitcase, Álvarez Saviñón was able to re-establish his fortune in Venezuela. It was said that in Caracas, "anywhere you looked something had been built by Virgilio Álvarez."
His mother, Thelma Renta, was the sister of fashion designer [[Oscar de la Renta]], and a major social figure in the Dominican Republic in her own right.
Álvarez Renta studied in Venezuela and the Dominican Republic, eventually earning a full scholarship to a Dominican University. He was also able to study in the United States, attending both the [[University of Michigan]] and [[Washington University]] in [[St. Louis]]. His performance in university did not go unnoticed, and he was offered scholarships for graduate work at both [[Cornell University]] in Ithaca, New York, and at the [[MIT Sloan School of Management]] in [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]]. He attended MIT Sloan and received a Masters in Finance. He would later establish a professorship there.
During his early career, Álvarez Renta was offered a number of jobs in the United States. He chose, instead to return to the Dominican Republic. At first, he engaged in the public sector, serving as Sub-Secretary of State for Industry and Commerce, advisor emeritus to the Presidency for Commerce and Finance, and director of CEDOPEX, the oversight agency for Dominican exports.
Having completed his work in the public sector, Álvarez Renta opened his own firm, Luis Álvarez Renta & Asociados, an investment banking firm focused on mergers and acquisitions. For the following thirty-three years, Álvarez Renta was known as the "King Midas" of the Dominican Republic, since his deals always made both sides significant amounts of money. Since the financial sector in the region was underdeveloped, he was often on both sides of a deal, as he was one of the only people in the region with the technical expertise required to process major corporate transactions.
As such, Álvarez Renta essentially created the marketplace for mergers and acquisitions in the Caribbean region, and became very wealthy in the process. An estimate of his wealth made during his divorce case in 2000 placed it at $148 million, although many believed it to be much more than that at the time.
Prior to the Baninter banking scandal, Álvarez Renta had accompanied former Dominican President [[Hipólito Mejía]] on many of his trips abroad, and was appointed ambassador to France on April 2, 2003. He decided to accept the appointment as part of his retirement, in order to effect positive change for the country by helping it negotiate a Free Trade Agreement with the European Union.
However, after Governor José Lois Malkún of the [[Banco Central de la República Dominicana|Central Bank of the Dominican Republic]]’s announcement that Álvarez Renta was involved in the Baninter debacle, Álvarez Renta resigned the post in order to avoid a dispute between President Mejia and his advisors.
In response to the announcement, Álvarez Renta took out full-page advertisements in the press, in which he declared he was innocent of all the charges made by the Central Bank. He also claimed to have ended his dealings with Baninter almost two years before its failure in 2003. Álvarez Renta was the only Dominican businessperson who is mentioned by name in the Central Bank report. The report said that overdrafts and loans totaling [[Dominican peso|RD]]$3.83 billion were erased at the start of this year in favor of the company Bankinvest, S.A., presided and managed by Luis Álvarez Renta.<ref>[http://dr1.com/news/2003/dnews051503.shtml DR1 Daily News-Short-term ambassadorial stay]</ref>
==Continuing Education==
One of the major keys to Álvarez Renta’s success was his commitment to continuing education. After graduating from MIT, he would go on to receive advanced degrees and certificates from such schools as the [[Harvard Business School]] and the [[Wharton School of Business]] at the [[University of Pennsylvania]].
This allowed Álvarez Renta to take new financial technologies and transplant them to the Caribbean marketplace. As an example, he is credited with introducing the "you set the price, I decide whether to buy or sell" process of negotiation to the region. His involvement at such a structural level in the development of the economic systems in the region ultimately made it possible for him to become successful.
==Doubts about Baninter==
Recently, many have expressed doubts about Álvarez Renta’s involvement in the Baninter scandal. He was accused by an administration that ended up being overrun with major corruption charges in a speech written by another financier, Andres Dauhajre, Jr., who had been an advisor to President Mejia and a lifelong rival of Álvarez Renta’s.
At the time of the accusation, Álvarez Renta stood to make US$100 million as part of the sale of a company he had bought that held exclusive contracts for the sale of duty-free items at every Dominican airport. Mejia's administration had challenged those contracts and lost, and many people were interested in acquiring them before the company's sale to a Spanish conglomerate was completed. (As a sidenote, these contracts would become a large part of the execution process in the lawsuit against Álvarez Renta in the United States, and were eventually turned over to the Central Bank of the Dominican Republic.)
The total amount that Álvarez Renta supposedly stole from Baninter was roughly US$59 million. It is presumably difficult to imagine him needing the money.
Álvarez Renta was also the only person in the scandal who was concurrently sued in the United States. Since the U.S. Federal Court is unable to compel testimony from Dominican citizens residing in the Dominican Republic (and none would testify voluntarily), Álvarez Renta claimed to be unable to call even a single witness in his own defense.
Ten of the original eleven charges filed in the criminal action against Álvarez Renta in the Dominican Republic were dropped before trial.
Álvarez Renta was responsible for trying to salvage Baninter by negotiating a merger with another Dominican bank, Banco del Progreso. The merger, which was approved by the Monetary Board of the Dominican Republic, was later undone by the Central Bank.
==After the Miami verdict== After being found liable in the [[U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida]] in November 2005, Álvarez Renta expressed that he blames former Baninter president Baez Figueroa for the colossal fraud that brought down the bank and all but decimated the [[Dominican economy]] in 2003. Álvarez Renta, who has been closely associated with the banking collapse, claimed he had no part in it and that Ramon Baez Figueroa and his deputy Marcos Baez Cocco were those responsible.<ref>DR1 Daily News-[http://dr1.com/news/2005/dnews111705.shtml#9 Renta blames Baez Figueroa]</ref> Proceedings in the Dominican Republic began on April 3, 2006 against Baninter's former president Ramon Báez Figueroa and the executives Vivian Lubrano and [[Marcos Báez Cocco]], Luis Álvarez Renta and [[Jesus Maria Ferrúa]]. The defense is headed by the famed attorney [[Marino Vinicio Castillo]], whose primary argument is that the authorities under Mejia's presidency (2000–2004) caused the bank's collapse.
On April 7, 2006 the Dominican Government announced it would offer legal and psychological support to former [[Miss Dominican Republic 1987]], Carmen Rita Perez Pellerano, in her demand that her ex-husband, Álvarez Renta, stop harassing her and that she be awarded custody of their daughter.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.dominicantoday.com/dr/this-and-that/2006/4/7/12212/Government-will-support-ex-beauty-queen-divorcing-the-convicted-Alvarez | title=Government will support ex-beauty queen divorcing the convicted Alvarez Renta | work=[[Dominican Today]] | date=7 April 2006 | accessdate=December 12, 2012 | location=Santo Domingo}}</ref> Álvarez-Renta won the case on the note that Ms. Perez was declared psychologically unfit to take care of their, at the time, 7-year-old daughter.
On July 16, 2008 L.A.R. was sent to the prison at Najayo, [[San Cristóbal, Dominican Republic|San Cristóbal]] (south), to begin serving a 10-year prison sentence.
Sentencing judge Saulo Ysabel Díaz issued the custody order around 7 p.m. July 16, after almost 12 hours of discussion with the condemned and his lawyers, who asked the court to reduce his sentence and that he be allowed to serve his time in prison in the jail at Aras Nacionales, [[Villa Mella]].
Álvarez Renta arrived early Thursday morning at Díaz's office in the company of his lawyers.
==Dealings with the presidencial candidate== It was later discovered that Álvarez Renta was the president of Maravedi, a company owned by [[Miguel Vargas Maldonado]], the candidate of the [[Dominican Revolutionary Party|PRD]] for the next presidential elections. That company was used to defraud the estate during the first years of the decade.<ref>[http://www.hoy.com.do/article.aspx?id=142489 Bienvenidos al Hoy Digital<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080304002750/http://www.hoy.com.do/article.aspx?id=142489 |date=2008-03-04 }}</ref>

A '''National Securities Identifying Number''', or '''NSIN''', is a generic nine-digit alpha numeric code which identifies a [[fungible]] [[security (finance)|security]]. The NSIN is issued by a [[national numbering agency]] (NNA) designated for that country. Regional substitute NNAs have been allocated the task of functioning as NNAs in those countries where NNAs have not yet been established. NSINs are used as part of the makeup of a product's [[International Securities Identifying Number|ISIN]].
==Sample NNA and NSIN designations== * In the [[United States]] and [[Canada]] the NNA is the CUSIP Services Bureau and the NSIN is the [[CUSIP]]. * In the [[United Kingdom]], the NNA is the [[London Stock Exchange]] and the NSIN is the [[SEDOL]]. * In [[France]], the NNA is [[Euroclear France]] and the NSIN used to be the [[Sicovam]]. As of July 1, 2003 SICOVAMs are no longer issued, [[ISIN]]s being used instead. * In [[Germany]], the NNA is [[Wertpapier-Mitteilungen]] and the NSIN is the [[Wertpapierkennummer|WKN]]. * In [[Switzerland]], the NNA is [[SIX Financial Information]] and the NSIN is the [[Valoren|Valor Number]]
== See also == * [[CUSIP]] * [[ISO 6166]] * [[ISO 10383]] * [[ISO 10962]] * [[International Securities Identifying Number]] * [[National numbering agency]]
==External links== *[http://www.anna-nna.com/ ANNA Directory: Numbering Agencies] for all participating countries

{{Infobox person | name = Neva Goodwin | birth_name = Neva Goodwin Rockefeller | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1944|6|1}} | parents = [[David Rockefeller]]
Margaret McGrath | spouse = Walter J. Kaiser
[[Bruce Mazlish]] (?–2016; his death) | children = 2 | relatives = See [[Rockefeller family]] }} '''Neva Goodwin Rockefeller''' (born June 1, 1944) is co-director of the [[Global Development And Environment Institute]] (GDAE) at [[Tufts University]], where she is a research associate at [[the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy]]{{cite web|url=http://www.ase.tufts.edu/gdae/about_us/researchers.html#goodwin|title=GDAE Researchers|work=tufts.edu}} and director of the Social Science Library: Frontier Thinking in Sustainable Development and Human Well-Being. Goodwin works towards a contextual economics theory that will have more relevance to contemporary real-world social and ecological concerns than does the dominant economic paradigm.[http://ase.tufts.edu/gdae/publications/ngcont-ec1.pdf Some Defining Characteristics of Contextual Economics] To this end, Goodwin is the lead author of two introductory university-level economics textbooks as well as online teaching modules,[http://www.ase.tufts.edu/gdae/education_materials/modules.html GDAE Teaching Modules on Social and Environmental Issues in Economics] along with editing two six-part series among other publications (see [[Neva Goodwin#Scholarship|below]]). Goodwin is also involved with efforts to motivate business to recognize social and ecological health as significant, long-term corporate goals. She is involved in [[socially responsible investing]] and served in leadership roles at organizations such as, most recently, the [[New Economy Coalition]],[http://neweconomy.net/directors New Economy Coalition] Winrock International Institute for Agricultural Development, [[Ceres (organization)|Ceres]], and the [[Sustainable Endowments Institute]].[http://www.ase.tufts.edu/gdae/about_us/cv/GoodwinCV.pdf Neva R. Goodwin Curriculum Vitae][http://philanthropyforum.org/members/neva-rockefeller-goodwin/ Neva Rockefeller Goodwin << Global Philanthropy Forum] == Scholarship == Goodwin is active in a variety of attempts to systematize and institutionalize an economic theory – "contextual economics" – that will have more relevance to contemporary real-world social and ecological concerns than does the dominant economic paradigm, along with university-level curriculum for these approaches and results, and action and policy to implement these understandings. Her work ranges across climate change, labor relations, and feminist economics (where she helped develop the notion of the [[Core sphere]] of production). She also seeks a deeper theoretic understanding from exposure to on-the-ground experiments in alternative socio-economic institutional design. She is the lead author of two introductory college-level textbooks: ''Microeconomics in Context''{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?isbn=0765638800|title=Microeconomics in Context - |work=google.com}}[http://ase.tufts.edu/gdae/publications/textbooks/microeconomics.html Microeconomics in Context (at GDAE)] and ''Macroeconomics in Context'',{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QMMqBwAAQBAJ&source=gbs_book_other_versions|title=Macroeconomics in Context - Neva Goodwin, Jonathan M. Harris, Julie A. Nelson, Brian Roach, Mariano Torras - Google Books|work=google.com}}[http://ase.tufts.edu/gdae/publications/textbooks/macroeconomics.html Macroeconomics in Context (at GDAE)] published by M.E. Sharpe and then Routledge. She is also the editor of two six-part book series: ''Evolving Values for a Capitalist World'' (University of Michigan Press),[https://www.press.umich.edu/browse/series/UM94 Evolving Values for a Capitalist World - The University of Michigan Press][http://www.ase.tufts.edu/gdae/publications/evolving_values/index.html GDAE - Evolving Values series] and ''Frontier Thinking in Economic Thought'' (Island Press).[http://islandpress.org/frontier-issues-economic-thought Frontier Thinking in Economic Thought | Island Press] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150415144234/http://islandpress.org/frontier-issues-economic-thought |date=2015-04-15 }}[http://www.ase.tufts.edu/gdae/publications/frontier_series/index.html GDAE (Frontier Issues in Economic Thought)] She is currently on the editorial board of ''[[Schmollers Jahrbuch]]'', Journal of Contextual Economics.[http://ejournals.duncker-humblot.de/loi/schm?cookieSet=1 Duncker & Humblor eJournals - Schmoller Jahrbuch] Goodwin's work has been published in various peer-reviewed journals and periodicals, including ''[[Real-world economics review|Real-World Economics Review]]'' (previously ''[[post-autistic economics]] review''), ''Our Planet: The Magazine of the United Nations Environment Programme'', ''Forum for Social Economics'', ''Growing the Economy through Global Warming Solutions'' (a series published by the Civil Society Institute), ''Opinion Sur'', ''Online Encyclopedia of Ecological Economics'' (published by the [[International Society for Ecological Economics]]), the ''Encyclopedia of Life Support Systems'', ''[[Review of Radical Political Economics]]'', ''Voprosy Ekonomiki'' [''Economic Questions''], ''Ecological Economics'', ''Green China Magazine'', ''[[World Development (journal)|World Development]]'' (editing a special edition), and ''[[Harvard Business Review|The Harvard Business Review]]''. Her work has also appeared in several edited compilations. GDAE also hosts several of her working papers.[http://www.ase.tufts.edu/gdae/about_us/cv/goodwin_cv.html GDAE: Neva Goodwin (Publications)] Her work has been reviewed in the ''[[Review of Radical Political Economics]]'',{{cite journal | last1 = Vernengo | first1 = Matias | year = 2007 | title = Book Review: New Thinking in Macroeconomics: Social, Institutional, and Environmental Perspectives | url = http://rrp.sagepub.com/content/39/1/145.extract | journal = Review of Radical Political Economics | volume = 39 | issue = 1| pages = 145–147 | doi=10.1177/0486613406296946}}{{cite journal | last1 = Maier | first1 = Mark | year = 2006 | title = Book Review: Dollars and Sense Anthologies: Real World Macro, Real World Micro, Real World Banking, The Environment in Crisis, Current Economic Issues, Real World Globalization | url = http://rrp.sagepub.com/content/38/3/481.extract | journal = Review of Radical Political Economics | volume = 38 | issue = 3| pages = 481–484 | doi=10.1177/0486613406291123}} ''Management Revue'',[https://www.jstor.org/stable/41771581 King, Mary C. “Book Review: ''Microeconomics in Context'' by Neva Goodwin, Julie A. Nelson, Frank Ackerman, Thomas Weisskopt”, ''Management Revue'', 17:2, Special Issue: Women in Management, Academia, and Other Professions: Stagnation or Progress?, (2006), pp. 209-210.] ''[[Journal of Economic Issues]]''[https://www.jstor.org/stable/4227741 Widerquist, Karl. “Book Review: ''The Political Economy of Inequality'' by Frank Ackerman, Neva Goodwin, Laurie Dougherty, Kevin Gallagher”, ''Journal of Economic Issues'', 35:4 (Dec., 2001), pp. 1054-1056.]''[[International Labour Review]]'',{{cite journal|doi=10.1111/j.1564-913X.2000.tb00411.x | volume=139 | issue=2 | title=Books | year=2000 | journal=International Labour Review | pages=213–249}} ''The [[Journal of Consumer Affairs]]'',[https://www.jstor.org/stable/23860490 Herrmann, Robert O. “Book Review: ''The Consumer Society, Volume 2: Frontier Issues in Economic Thought'' by Neva R. Goodwin, Frank Ackerman, David Kiron”, ''The Journal of Consumer Affairs'' 31:2 (Winter 1997), pp. 391-394.] ''[[The Journal of Environment & Development]]'',{{cite journal | last1 = Young | first1 = Kevin | year = 1996 | title = Book Review: A Survey of Ecological Economics, edited by Rajaram Krishnan, Jonathan M. Harris, and Neva R. Goodwin. Washington, DC, and Covelo, CA: Island Press. 384 pp., with index | url = http://jed.sagepub.com/content/5/2/259.extract | journal = The Journal of Environment & Development | volume = 5 | issue = 2| pages = 259–261 | doi=10.1177/107049659600500210}} ''Southern Economic Journal'',{{cite journal | last1 = Larson | first1 = Bruce | year = 1992 | title = Book Review: ''Social Economics: An Alternative Theory. Volume 1: Building Anew on Marshall's Principles'' by Neva Goodwin | journal = Southern Economic Journal | volume = 59 | issue = 2| pages = 340–341 | jstor=1060551}} ''[[The Economic Journal]]''.{{cite journal | last1 = Loasby | first1 = Brian J | year = | title = Book Review: ''Social Economics: An Alternative Theory: Volume I, Building Anew on Marshall's Principles'' by Neva R. Goodwin | journal = The Economic Journal | volume = 102 | issue = 413| pages = 1004–1006 | jstor=2234615 | doi = 10.2307/2234615}} She has lectured widely, including at the Club of Rome and The Smithsonian Institution Grand Challenges Consortia;[http://www.ase.tufts.edu/gdae/pubs/te/Smithsonian.pdf 2012 Labor’s Declining Share and Future Quality of Life] [[MIT]];[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_YuNqSsp2uk Neva Goodwin at MIT on "A New Economics for the 21st Century" ] Thirtieth Annual E. F. Schumacher Lectures; [[New School For Social Research]]; University of Utah; the [[Kennedy School of Government]]; the Yale School of Forestry and Environmental Studies; the Cambridge Forum; Environmental Grantmakers Association; the University of Moscow; the University of Cambridge; the EPA; the Russian Society for Ecological Economics; the American Economic Association; Socially Responsible Investing (SRI in the Rockies); the American Association of Legal Scholars; the U.S. Society for Ecological Economics (keynote address); the Eastern Economics Association; the Atlantic International Economic Society; the International Society for Quality of Life Studies (keynote address); the Boston Theological Institute in conjunction with The American Association for the Advancement of Science; the UN Development Program; the Society for the Advancement of Socio-Economics; and the World Institute for International Development, Helsinki. Goodwin has helped arrange a variety of conferences, seminars, and symposia at Pocantico Conference Center,[http://www.ase.tufts.edu/gdae/Conference2006.html Growth vs. Sustainability? Economic Responses to Ecological Challenges, 2006 November 9-11] Tufts University, Harvard University, Boston University and elsewhere, and with the support of the [[Rockefeller Brothers Fund]], [[Richard Lounsbery Foundation]], [[Ford Foundation]], [[MacArthur Foundation]], [[Center for International Development at Harvard University]] (then, the Harvard Institute for International Development), [[William and Flora Hewlett Foundation|Hewlett Foundation]], and more. Goodwin is also director of a project that has developed a "Social Science Library: Frontier Thinking in Sustainable Development and Human Well-Being." Containing a bibliography of more than 9,000 titles, including full text PDFs of about a third of these, this material will be sent on USB drives or CDs to all university libraries in 137 developing countries. == Public activity == Goodwin is currently on the board of advisors at [[Sustainable Endowments Institute]]; and the president of the Mount Desert Land and Garden Preserve.[http://gardenpreserve.org/about-the-preserve/board-of-directors.html Land & Garden Preserve | Board & Officers] Goodwin has previously worked with the Institute for New Economic Thinking (INET); [[Ceres (organization)|Ceres]] (Coalition for Environmentally Responsible Economy; on their board of directors); [[College of the Atlantic]]; Bar Harbor, Maine (as the vice-chair of the board); the [[Rockefeller Brothers Fund]] (as a trustee, and then vice-chair of the board); the Human Development and Capability Association (as a founding fellow); the International Society for Ecological Economics; Washington, D.C., President's Council on Sustainable Development; Task Force on Population & Consumption; U.S. Department of Commerce, [[Economic Development Administration]]; the Committee for the Political Economy of the Good Society (PEGS; as a founding board member); the World Bank; the International Center for Research on Women, Washington, D.C. (as a trustee, and committee chair); Technology + Economics consulting firm; the New Community Development Corporation, Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD); and the Boston Society of Architects.[http://www.sourcewatch.org/index.php/Neva_R._Goodwin Neva R. Goodwin - SourceWatch] Goodwin was also active in organizing [[Rockefeller family|her family]] to attempt to reason with the present and former CEOs of [[ExxonMobil]] regarding [[climate change]], directly and through shareholder resolutions. The family had some success in persuading the company to reduce its public stance of ridiculing the science of climate change. == Early life and family == Goodwin attended the [[Chapin School]] in New York [https://www.nytimes.com/1964/09/17/neva-rockefeller-engaged-to-wed-gerald-medearis.html] and graduated from [[Concord Academy]], Class of 1962.["Neva Goodwin, Class of 1962: Rethinking Economics", ''Concord Academy Magazine'', Spring 2012] Goodwin received an A.B. in English literature; Magna Cum Laude, [[Phi Beta Kappa]] from [[Harvard College]], Class of 1966. Her senior thesis, "The Deciphered Heart: A Study of Conrad Aiken's Poetry and Prose Fiction,"[http://id.lib.harvard.edu/aleph/013187149/catalog The Deciphered Heart : A Study of Conrad Aiken's Poetry and Prose Fiction | Harvard University] was published in full in the 75th Anniversary Year edition of the Sewanee Review the following summer, under the pen-name Jennifer Aldrich.{{Cite journal | last = Aldrich | first = Jennifer | title = The Deciphered Heart: Conrad Aiken's Poetry and Prose Fiction | journal = The Sewanee Review | volume = 75 | issue = 3 | pages = 485–520 | publisher = The Johns Hopkins University Press | date = Summer 1967 | jstor = 27541553 | postscript = .}} After working closely with [[Buckminster Fuller]] for seven years to establish and organize the [[Design science revolution|Design Science]] Institute (now the Buckminster Fuller Institute), and then for a couple of years as a consultant, she returned to academia to receive a MPA from Harvard Kennedy School ('82) and a Ph.D. in Economics from Boston University ('87). Her dissertation, ''Back to the Fork: What We Have Derived from Marshallian Economics and what We Might Have Derived'', became her first book in 1991: ''Social Economics: An Alternative Theory: Building Anew on Marshall's Principles ''.[https://www.amazon.com/Social-Economics-Marshalls-Principle-Alternative/dp/0333523725 Social Economics: Building Anew on Marshall's Principle v. 1: An Alternative Theory: Neva R. Goodwin: 9780333523728: Amazon.com: Books]Several chapters of ''Social Economics'' are available online care of [http://ase.tufts.edu/gdae/advancing_theory/theory_pubs.html#social GDAE]. While a student at BU, she co-taught courses with S. M. Miller[http://keywiki.org/S._M._Miller S. M. Miller - KeyWiki] and [[Paul Streeten]], and was a research associate and coordinator of the Global Issues Program at BU's World Development Institute, as well as the Director of Program Development at The African Studies Center. Goodwin was also visiting fellow at the World Institute for Development Economics Research (WIDER) of the United Nations University in Helsinki, and a research associate at the Instituto Interamericano De Cooperacion Para La Agricultura (IICA), Buenos, Aires, Argentina, before moving to Tufts University in 1991. Goodwin is the widow of [[Bruce Mazlish]] and is the mother of two and grandmother of three.[http://ase.tufts.edu/gdae/Pubs/news/GoodwinCABio.pdf "Neva Goodwin, Class of 1962: Rethinking Economics", ''Concord Academy Magazine'', Spring 2012] She is an avid photographer, especially of [[lichen]]s.[http://www.nevasphotos.org Neva's Photos] Goodwin is a fourth-generation member of the [[Rockefeller family]]. She is the third child of [[David Rockefeller]] and Margaret McGrath, along with siblings David, [[Abby Rockefeller|Abby]], [[Peggy Dulany|Peggy]], [[Richard Rockefeller|Richard]], and [[Eileen Rockefeller Growald|Eileen]]. "Goodwin" is originally her middle name, after an ancestor on her mother's side (no relation to other Goodwin economists). == Bibliography == NB: See also Goodwin's curriculum vitae at her [[Global Development And Environment Institute|GDAE]] home page.[ase.tufts.edu/gdae/about_us/researchers.html#goodwin GDAE Researchers] *''Principles of Economics in Context'', co-author with Jonathan Harris, [[Julie A. Nelson]], Brian Roach, & Mariano Torras; M.E. Sharpe, 2014 *''Microeconomics In Context: Third Edition'', co-author with Jonathan Harris, [[Julie A. Nelson]], Brian Roach, & Mariano Torras; M.E. Sharpe, 2014. **Italian translation, 2009 **''Transitional Economies edition'', Neva Goodwin, Thomas E. Weisskopf and [[Frank Ackerman]] ***Vietnamese translation, Commercial University of Hanoi, 2002 ***Russian translation, Moscow State University for the Humanities, 2002 **First Editions by Houghton Mifflin Co., Boston **Co-authors of First and Second Editions: [[Julie A. Nelson]], [[Frank Ackerman]] and Thomas Weisskopf *''Macroeconomics in Context: Second Edition'', co-authors: Jonathan Harris, [[Julie A. Nelson]], Brian Roach, & Mariano Torras; M.E. {{about|the San Francisco office building|the Los Angeles office building|One California Plaza|the bank|OneCalifornia Bank|the anti-partition California political group|Six Californias}} {{other uses|1 California (disambiguation){{!}}1 California}} {{Infobox building | name = One California | image = One California Street, San Francisco.jpg | caption = | alternate_names = Airtouch Building
Mutual Benefit Life Building | location = One California Street
[[San Francisco]], [[California]] | coordinates = {{coord|37.7932|-122.3972|region:US-CA|display=inline,title}} | pushpin_map = United States San Francisco Central#California#USA | completion_date = 1969 | building_type = Commercial offices | roof = {{convert|133.5|m|abbr=on}} | floor_count = 32 | elevator_count = 13 | parking = 135 | cost = | floor_area = {{convert|484,512|sqft|abbr=on}} | architect = [[Welton Becket Associates]] | structural_engineer= | main_contractor = | developer = | owner = One California Street Partners | management = [[CBRE Group]] | references = {{ctbuh|12783}}{{emporis|118733}}{{skyscraperpage|1844}}{{structurae|s0021837}}{{cite web |url=http://www.cbre.us/o/sanfrancisco/properties/one-california-street/Pages/home.aspx |title=One California Street |publisher=CBRE |accessdate=March 14, 2013}} }} '''One California''' is a {{convert|133.5|m|abbr=on}}, 32-[[storey|story]] office [[skyscraper]] completed in 1969 in the [[Financial District, San Francisco|Financial District]] of [[San Francisco]], [[California]]. It is the [[List of tallest buildings in San Francisco|31st-tallest building]] in the city. The architect of the building was [[Welton Becket Associates]]. ==History== The building was constructed on the site of the previously demolished [[Fife Building]], and was one of the earliest modern skyscrapers constructed in the city. It was the fifth tallest building in San Francisco when it was completed, but is no longer in the top 30.[[List of tallest buildings in San Francisco]] One California was one of three buildings, the other two being [[555 California Street]] and [[McKesson Plaza]], that was featured in a 1970 ''[[Newsweek]]'' article widely thought to have coined the term "[[Manhattanization]]". In 1995, Shorenstein became the sole owner of the tower and invested US$5 million in an extensive lobby and plaza renovation.{{cite news |url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/article-1G1-16765471/shorenstein-solo-run-real.html |title=Shorenstein's solo run: real estate firm inks refinancing and buyout deals |work=San Francisco Business Times |author=Ginsberg, Steve |date=March 3, 1995 |accessdate=March 11, 2013 |quote=Workers have already taken down the building's Mutual Benefit Life sign and will put up AirTouch's logo in April.}} ===Corporate signage=== One California is one of very few[[425 California Street]] and the [[Bank of California Building (San Francisco)|Bank of California Tower]] are other examples. downtown office skyscrapers in San Francisco to feature corporate signage at the top of the tower. When it was constructed, the building's signage read "[[Mutual Benefit Life]]" for the insurance company.{{cite web |url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/philip_wgtn/3289906106/sizes/o/ |title=Downtown SF Aug 1971 |publisher=Flickr |author=philip_wgtn_nz}} Some time after the building went up, the San Francisco Planning Code was changed to prohibit signs above {{convert|100|ft}} on new buildings.{{cite web |url=http://www.sf-planning.org/Modules/ShowDocument.aspx?documentid=5909 |title=Letter of Determination - One California Street |date=January 25, 2007 |author=Lawrence B. Badiner, Zoning Administrator |accessdate=March 11, 2013}} Existing buildings were grandfathered in and allowed for replacing signs as long as the new sign is no larger in surface area and projection than the existing sign. After Mutual Benefit Life went out of business, the building's sign was changed in April 1995 to the logo for [[AirTouch]], which had its headquarters in the building."[https://web.archive.org/web/19980222065911/http://www.airtouch.com/airtouch/contact/ Contact Information]." [[AirTouch]]. Retrieved on January 10, 2010. In October 2005, the AirTouch signs were removed and replaced with the current [[US Bank]] logo.{{cite web |url=http://www.spiderglobal.com/press_cal.html |title=Spider Delivers on Rigging Commitments for Sign Replacement Project |work=SafeWorks, LLC |date=October 7, 2005 |accessdate=March 11, 2013 |quote=All rigging moves were required to be completed during the day under tight time and safety constraints to enable the contractor to perform the replacement of the existing 'Airtouch' signs with the new 'US Bank' signs under lights at night.}} ==Tenants== *[[Grosvenor Group|Grosvenor Americas]][http://www.grosvenor.com/Contact Grosvenor - Contact] *[[Lennar Corporation|Lennar Urban]] *[[Salesforce.com]][http://www.costar.com/News/Article/Salesforcecom-Expands-in-San-Francisco/93680 Salesforce.com Expands in San Francisco] *[[LendingHome]]{{cite web |url=https://www.lendinghome.com/contact |title=LendingHome - Contact}} *[[Perella Weinberg Partners]]{{cite web |url=https://www.pwpartners.com/who-we-are |title=Who We Are - Perella Weinberg Partners}} ==See also== {{Portal|San Francisco Bay Area}} * [[List of tallest buildings in San Francisco]] ==Notes== {{Reflist|group=note}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * {{official|onecaliforniastreet.com}} {{Buildings in San Francisco|state=collapsed}} [[Category:Skyscraper office buildings in San Francisco]] [[Category:Financial District, San Francisco]] [[Category:Welton Becket buildings]] [[Category:Office buildings completed in 1969]] [[Category:Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design gold certified buildings]]

A '''product manager''' is a professional role which is responsible for the development of products for an organization, known as the practice of [[product management]]. For both physical products and virtual ones such as software, product managers work to define the business strategy behind a product, as well as specifying its functional requirements.
==Definition== Diverse interpretations regarding the role of the product manager are the norm, and thus precisely defining the scope of the role is often difficult. The product manager title is often used in many ways to describe drastically different duties and responsibilities. Even within the [[high-tech]] industry where [[product management]] is better defined, the product manager's job description varies widely among companies. This is due to tradition and intuitive interpretations by different individuals.
A product manager considers numerous factors such as intended customer or user of a product, the products offered by the competition, and how well the product fits with the company's business model. Generally, a product manager may manage one or more tangible product lines. However, the term may be used to describe a person who manages intangible products, such as music, information, and services. In the financial services industry (banking, insurance etc.), product managers manage products (for example, credit card portfolios), their profit and loss, and also determine the business development strategy.
In some companies, the product manager also performs the functions of similar roles, such as:
* [[Product marketing]] manager: may perform all [[Marketing communications|outbound marketing]] activities in the older sense of the term * [[Project manager]]: may perform all activities related to schedule and resource management * [[Program manager]]: may perform activities related to schedule, resource, and cross-functional execution * [[Product owner]]: a popular role in Agile development methodology, may perform all activities related to a self-encapsulated feature or feature set plan, development and releases. * Technical product manager (TPM): similar to product owner, but may perform all activities from technology perspective. * [[Product designer]]: closer to UX designer but more focus on entire function flows.
== Product management in software development ==
The role of the product manager was originally created to manage the complexity of the product lines of a business, as well as to ensure that those products were profitable. Product managers can come from many different backgrounds, because their primary skills involve working well with customers and understanding the problems the product is intended to solve.<ref name="Geracie2010a">{{cite book|author=Greg Geracie|title=Take Charge Product Management|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6SgULkK_S6UC|date=July 2010|publisher=Greg Geracie|isbn=978-0-615-37927-2|pp=16–17}}</ref>
A product manager is responsible for orchestrating the various activities associated with ensuring that a product is delivered that meets users' needs. A software product manager's role varies as the software moves through its lifecycle; earlier in the development process the product manager meets the intended audience of the product to engage in [[requirements elicitation]],<ref>{{cite book|last=Zieliński|first=Krzysztof|title=Software Engineering: Evolution and Emerging Technologies|year=2005|publisher=IOS Press|location=Amsterdam|isbn=1-58603-559-2|pages=215|edition=2nd printing.|author2=Szmuc, Tomasz }}</ref> whereas later in the lifecycle the product manager's primary focus may be in [[acceptance testing]] of the product. Throughout all the stages of the product development process, the product manager represents the needs of end-users, evaluates market trends and competition, and uses this information to determine what features to build. For example, a product manager may decide a feature is needed because users are asking for it, or because the feature is needed to stay competitive. In order to facilitate this decision making process the product manager may set out a vision for the product or a general framework for making product decisions. The product manager also ensures an atmosphere of cohesiveness and focused collaboration between all the members of the team, all in the interest of driving the product forward.<ref name="Cohen2010a">{{cite book|author=Greg Cohen|title=Agile Excellence for Product Managers: A Guide to Creating Winning Products with Agile Development Teams|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IoX8lOdSWWQC|year=2010|publisher=Happy About|isbn=978-1-60773-074-3}}</ref> Product managers are often thought of as sitting at the intersection of business, design, and technology.
Within an [[agile software development]] environment day-to-day responsibilities of a product manager include creating and prioritizing the product backlog, which is a list of things to be done by the development team. The product backlog is often made up of [[user story|user stories]], "a placeholder for a conversation between the product manager... and the development team." These are brief narrative descriptions of what a feature should do, including a checklist of items that are required to be in place in order for the feature to be considered done, called the [[Acceptance testing|acceptance criteria]]. The details of how the feature is developed are worked out by developers and designers. At the end of the development sprint, the product manager is responsible for verifying that the acceptance criteria have been met; only then is the work on the feature officially done.<ref name="Cohen2010b">{{cite book|author=Greg Cohen|title=Agile Excellence for Product Managers: A Guide to Creating Winning Products with Agile Development Teams|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IoX8lOdSWWQC|year=2010|publisher=Happy About|isbn=978-1-60773-074-3|page=57}}</ref>
Notable individuals who have held the role of product manager in a software development company include [[Sundar Pichai]] (CEO of [[Google]]) [[Marissa Mayer]] (former CEO of [[Yahoo!]]), [[Premal Shah]] (president of [[Kiva (organization)|Kiva.org]]), [[Reid Hoffman]] (founder of [[LinkedIn]]), and [[Kevin Systrom]] (founder of [[Instagram]]).
The need for a separate product manager role depends on the size of an organization; in smaller organizations, the CEO may take on the responsibilities of product manager.<ref name="Geracie2010b">{{cite book|author=Greg Geracie|title=Take Charge Product Management|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6SgULkK_S6UC|date=July 2010|publisher=Greg Geracie|isbn=978-0-615-37927-2|page=18}}</ref>

[[Thomas Nelson Page]] (cousin) |awards = |laterwork = }} '''Richard Lucian Page''' (December 20, 1807 – August 9, 1901) was a [[United States Navy]] officer who joined the [[Confederate States Navy]] and later became a [[History of Confederate States Army Generals#Brigadier general|brigadier general]] in the [[Confederate States Army]] during the American Civil War. ==Early life== Richard L. Page was born in [[Clarke County, Virginia]] on December 20, 1807 to William Byrd Page (1768-1812) and Ann (Lee) Page (b.1776). He has a [[maternal]] cousin in the future Confederate Full General [[Robert E. Lee]] and a [[paternal]] cousin of the poet [[Thomas Nelson Page]]. Another maternal relative is [[Charles Lee (Attorney General)|Charles Lee]] who was [[U.S. Attorney General]] during the [[Washington Administration]] and the [[John Adams Administration]]. He attended the common schools in Clarke County and in [[Alexandria, Virginia]]. ==Early Military Service== Richard Lucian Page joined the [[U.S. Navy]] as a midshipman on March 12, 1824, and his first assignment in 1824–1825 was on board the {{USS|John Adams|1799|6}} of the U.S. Navy West Indies Squadron led by Commodore [[David Porter (naval officer)|David Porter]]. In 1825, he was ordered to the {{USS|Brandywine||6}} and was with the crew when it carried General [[Marquis de Lafayette]] back to [[France]] under the leadership of U.S. Navy Captain [[Charles Morris (naval officer)|Charles Morris]]. Now in [[Europe]], Midshipman Page was transferred to the {{USS|Constitution||6}} where he served with this U.S. Navy [[Mediterranean Squadron (United States)|Mediterranean Squadron]] ship until it returned to the port of [[Boston, Massachusetts]] on [[Independence Day (United States)|Independence Day]], 1828. Page's next assignment came on the {{USS|Constellation|1797|6}} after which he prepared for his naval examination. In 1830-1834, Passed Midshipman and Sailing Master Richard Page served on board the {{USS|Concord|1828|6}} with the U.S. Navy Mediterranean Squadron. On March 26, 1834, Richard Page was commissioned a U.S. Navy Lieutenant and was ordered to serve on the {{USS|Enterprise|1831|6}} which was going overseas. He was then transferred to the {{USS|Ontario|1813|6}}, then transferred back to the ''Enterprise'' and then finally landing on the {{USS|Peacock|1828|6}} which brought him back to the United States of America in October, 1837. After his around-the-world tour of duty, Lieutenant Page was given a two-years leave of absence to visit Europe in 1837-1839. Upon returning to duty in 1839, Page will serve at the [[Gosport Navy Yard]] as an ordnance officer. During this tour of duty at Norfolk, he married a local woman, Alexina Taylor, in 1841; they would have four children. After duty at the navy yard, he then took to the seas again on board the {{USS|Macedonian|1836|6}} for two years. In 1844-1845, he was back with the U.S. Navy Mediterranean Squadron on board the {{USS|Fairfield|1828|6}}. Upon returning to the United States in 1845, he served with the docked {{USS|Pennsylvania|1837|6}} at the U.S. Navy Norfolk Naval Ship Yard. ==The Mexican American War And Afterwards== During the [[Mexican–American War]] of 1846–1848, he served for two years as Lieutenant Commander on board the {{USS|Independence|1814|6}}. This ship served as the flagship for U.S. Navy Pacific Squadron Commander, Commodore [[William Shubrick]]. After this war, in 1849–1852, he was back doing ordnance duty at the U.S. Navy Norfolk Navy Ship Yard. Then in 1852–1854, Lieutenant Commander Page served as commander of the {{USS|Perry|1843|6}} with the U.S. Navy [[Africa Squadron]]. Upon returning from Africa, Page was back at Norfolk, this time as an executive officer and a Member of the Retiring Board. On September 14, 1855, U.S. Navy Lieutenant Commander Richard Page was promoted to commander in the midst of his 1854–1857 service while at [[Norfolk, Virginia]]. In 1857–1859, Commander Page was with the U.S. Navy [[East India Squadron]] serving as commander of the {{USS|Germantown|1846|6}}. Then he returned to Norfolk where serve from 1859 to 1861. As soon as the [[Commonwealth of Virginia]] ceded from the Union, U.S. Navy Commander Richard Lucian Page resigned his rank and office while at the Navy Yard. ==With The Confederates== Now out of the U.S. Navy, Richard L. Page next served as a naval aide-de-camp to the [[Governor of Virginia]] [[John Letcher]] with special duties to organize a State of Virginia Navy. While in this Office, Page supervised the building of fortifications at the mouth of the [[James River]] as well as those on the [[Nansemond River]] and on the [[Pagan River]]. On June 10, 1861, Richard Page received a commission as a Confederate States of America Navy Commander. Prior to the evacuation at [[Norfolk, Virginia]], he served at the ship yard. Upon being promoted to C.S. Navy captain a short time later, Page went on to establish the ordnance and construction depot located at [[Charlotte, North Carolina]], which he would largely manage during the period of 1861–1864. During this time of 1861–1864, however, he would also briefly be in command of C.S. Navy forces at [[Savannah, Georgia]], and would also be active in the [[Battle of Port Royal]] in November 1861, where he served on the {{ship|CSS|Savannah|gunboat|6}} under the fleet command of C.S. Navy squadron Flag Officer [[Josiah Tattnall]]. Then on March 1, 1864, Richard Page left the C.S. Navy to join the C.S. Army; he got a commission as a C.S. Army brigadier general. He was then assigned to take command of the outer defenses of the C.S. Army held location at [[Mobile Bay, Alabama]] and would set up his headquarters at [[Fort Morgan (Alabama)|Fort Morgan]]. Brigadier General Page was in command of the Confederate garrison that controlled Fort Morgan, Alabama during the Union's attacks on Mobile Bay. Fort Morgan withstood the Union attack on April 5, 1864, but was besieged on April 9. Then on August 8, 1864, a 10,000-man and 200-cannon Union task force arrived to challenge Page's 400-man and 26-cannon Confederate force. Union task force staff summoned Page and told him to surrender; he replied that he would defend the fort to the end. Federal troops then moved their works closer to the outdated fort for the next two weeks. Then on August 22, 1864, heavy Union cannon fire replaced the lighter cannon fire of the previous two weeks. For the next 12 hours, 3,000 Union cannon shells were thrown at the fort. This Union cannon fire started some fires in the fort and threatened to ignite the Confederate powder magazine, and so the defenders put the powder kegs in the cisterns. On August 23 Brigadier General Richard Lucian Page unconditionally surrendered the fort, because his troops had little usable gunpowder. Indignant, he broke his sword over his knee instead of surrendering his sword to the Federals. Page's situation was further worsened when he was suspected of destroying munitions and works within the fort after he had agreed to surrender. He was arrested by the Federal authorities and imprisoned at [[Fort Delaware]] on [[Pea Patch Island]] until September 1865.{{cite book|last1=Wright|first1=John D.|title=The Routledge Encyclopedia of Civil War Era Biographies |page=444 |date=2013 |publisher=Routledge |location=New York |isbn=9780415878036 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=V_wpKWzSmvUC}} ==Late life== Page returned to Norfolk after the war, eventually becoming superintendent of public schools from 1875 to 1883. He died in [[Blue Ridge Summit, Pennsylvania]], on August 9, 1901{{cite DANFS |title=Richard L. Page |url=https://www.history.navy.mil/research/histories/ship-histories/danfs/r/richard-l-page-.html}} and is buried in Cedar Grove Cemetery, [[Norfolk, Virginia]]. ==Honors== In ''Confederate Military History: Volume 3'' [[Clement A. Evans]], himself a former C.S. Army Brigadier General, was moved to write the following on the defense of Fort Morgan in August 22–23 of 1864, "The defense of Fort Morgan, under the command of (Brigadier) General Page, is one of the most celebrated instances of heroism in the history of the war." The {{USS|Richard L. Page|FFG-5|6}}, a [[Brooke-class frigate]] built for the United States Navy in 1965, was named in his honor. ==See also== {{portal|American Civil War|Biography}} *[[List of American Civil War generals (Confederate)]] ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== * Eicher, John H., and [[David J. Eicher]], ''Civil War High Commands.'' Stanford: Stanford University Press, 2001. {{ISBN|978-0-8047-3641-1}}. * Evans, Clement A. ''Confederate Military History: Volume 3'' Atlanta, Georgia: Evans' Confederate Publishing Company, 1899. pp. 641–644. * Sifakis, Stewart. ''Who Was Who in the Civil War.'' New York: Facts On File, 1988. {{ISBN|978-0-8160-1055-4}}. * [[Ezra J. Warner (historian)|Warner, Ezra J.]] ''Generals in Gray: Lives of the Confederate Commanders.'' Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press, 1959. {{ISBN|978-0-8071-0823-9}}. ==External links== *{{Find a Grave|11042}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Page, Richard Lucian}} [[Category:1807 births]] [[Category:1901 deaths]] [[Category:Confederate States Army brigadier generals]] [[Category:People of Virginia in the American Civil War]] [[Category:People from Clarke County, Virginia]] [[Category:Page family of Virginia|Richard Lucian Page]] [[Category:American people of English descent]] [[Category:Confederate States Navy captains]] [[Category:United States Navy officers]]
